section1.title: Understanding Pump & Dump Schemes
section1.p1: A pump and dump scheme is a form of securities fraud where perpetrators artificially inflate the price of a stock through false and misleading positive statements (the 'pump'), then sell their shares at the inflated price (the 'dump'), leaving other investors with worthless stock.
section1.p2: These schemes have evolved with technology and now frequently use social media platforms, messaging apps, and coordinated online campaigns to create artificial demand and manipulate stock prices.
section1.p3: Pump and dump schemes are particularly dangerous because:
list: They target retail investors who may lack sophisticated market knowledge.
They often involve penny stocks with low liquidity, making manipulation easier.
They can cause massive losses for unsuspecting investors within hours or days.
They undermine market integrity and investor confidence.

phase1.title: Target Selection
phase1.description: Fraudsters identify low-priced, thinly-traded stocks that are easier to manipulate.

phase2.title: Accumulation
phase2.description: Perpetrators secretly buy large quantities of the target stock at low prices.

phase3.title: Promotion (PUMP)
phase3.description: Launch aggressive marketing campaigns to artificially drive up demand and price.

phase4.title: Distribution (DUMP)
phase4.description: Sell accumulated shares at peak prices, causing the stock to crash.

section3.title: Warning Signs & Red Flags
section3.p1: Learning to identify pump and dump warning signs is crucial for protecting your investments:
section3.warningSign1: Stock promoted heavily on social media with claims like 'This stock will 10X in the next week!' with rocket emojis and screenshots of profits.
section3.warningSign2: Penny stock suddenly has 50x normal trading volume and is up 200% in one day with no company news.
section3.warningSign3: WhatsApp group admin claims to have 'insider information' about a stock and says 'buy now, sell tomorrow for guaranteed 50% profit'.

wolfWallStreet.title: The Wolf of Wall Street (1990s)
wolfWallStreet.description: Jordan Belfort and Stratton Oakmont manipulated penny stocks through cold calling and false promotions.

socialMediaPumps.title: Social Media Pump Groups (2020-2021)
socialMediaPumps.description: Coordinated campaigns on Discord, Telegram, and Reddit manipulated various cryptocurrency and stock prices.

celebrityCryptoPumps.title: Celebrity Crypto Pumps (2021-2022)
celebrityCryptoPumps.description: Various celebrities promoted cryptocurrencies without disclosure, leading to massive price manipulation.
